item.title: [KLI] Klingon Verbs(1)
item.description: Klingon verbs do not have tense (past, present, future), so a verb such as yaj could mean “understands, understood, will understand”. In grammar, a subject is the one doing the action and an object is the one the action is done to. Klingon verbs show the subject and the object of verbs by means of prefixes. The most important verb prefixes are: jI- = I (subject), no object bI- = you (subject), no object – for single person vI- = I (subject), him/her/it/them (object) Da- = you (subject), him/her/it/them (object) – for single person If the subject is third person (he/she/it/they) and has either no object or a third-person object (him/her/it/them), then the verb has no prefix.

item.description: a b ch D e gh H I j l m n ng o p Q q r S t tlh u v w y ' Notes: In Klingon, case matters. Many letters are always lowercase (even at the beginning of a sentence!) and some are always uppercase.
